hinges.description: Dr. Candy secretly doses Franklin with laudanum
hinges.actual_outcome: Candy slips laudanum into Franklin's drink as petty revenge for being mocked about medicine

alternatives.outcome: Candy lets the insult go, does nothing
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Very plausible. Candy is a professional; petty revenge via drugging is out of character for most physicians. His wounded pride would need to be extreme.

alternatives.outcome: Candy confronts Franklin directly about the insult
immediate_effects: Public argument at the dinner party
Social awkwardness but no medical intervention
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Moderately plausible. Candy is proud but not confrontational. More likely to seethe privately.

alternatives.outcome: Candy doses Franklin but someone notices
immediate_effects: Betteredge or a servant sees something suspicious
Franklin is warned or the drink is replaced
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Candy is discreet, but busy household means witnesses are possible.

hinges.description: Rachel sees Franklin take the diamond
hinges.actual_outcome: Rachel stays silent, assumes Franklin is a thief, breaks off engagement

alternatives.outcome: Rachel confronts Franklin immediately that night
immediate_effects: Franklin reveals he has no memory of taking it
They search for the diamond together
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Highly plausible. Rachel is direct and principled. Her silence requires wounded pride to override her natural directness.

alternatives.outcome: Rachel tells her mother what she saw
immediate_effects: Family closes ranks, no police called
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Moderately plausible. Rachel is secretive about emotional matters, but might seek her mother's guidance when frightened.

alternatives.outcome: Rachel screams, waking the household
immediate_effects: Franklin caught in the act (though confused)
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Rachel is self-controlled. Screaming would be out of character unless truly terrified.

alternatives.outcome: Rachel doesn't see it — she's asleep or elsewhere
immediate_effects: Diamond goes missing with no witness
Investigation proceeds without Rachel's secret knowledge
Rachel has no reason to break engagement
Mystery is purely external, no dramatic irony
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible as counterfactual. Her witnessing requires her to be awake and positioned correctly at exactly the right moment.

hinges.actual_outcome: Rosanna hides the nightgown to protect Franklin, whom she loves

alternatives.outcome: Rosanna reports the nightgown to Betteredge
immediate_effects: Evidence immediately connects Franklin to the scene
Franklin must explain the paint stain
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility given her feelings. Reporting would doom Franklin. Her love makes concealment almost inevitable.

alternatives.outcome: Rosanna destroys the nightgown completely
immediate_effects: No letter, no Shivering Sand package
Franklin can never be exonerated via the nightgown
Mystery may never be fully solved
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible. Simpler than her elaborate hiding scheme. But she wants to preserve it as proof of her devotion.

alternatives.outcome: Rosanna confronts Franklin directly with the nightgown
immediate_effects: Franklin is bewildered — has no memory
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Rosanna is too shy and socially anxious to confront the man she loves. Her class position makes this even harder.

alternatives.outcome: Someone else finds the nightgown first
immediate_effects: Penelope or another servant discovers it
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Moderately plausible. Depends on timing and laundry procedures. Rosanna finding it first requires specific access.

hinges.description: Godfrey takes diamond from unconscious Franklin
hinges.actual_outcome: Godfrey seizes opportunity, takes diamond from Franklin's hand, pawns it to cover debts

alternatives.outcome: Godfrey doesn't see Franklin with the diamond
immediate_effects: Franklin leaves diamond somewhere in his room
Diamond found next morning in obvious location
Mystery is about sleepwalking, not crime
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible. Godfrey seeing Franklin requires him to be awake and in the right place. Could easily miss it.

alternatives.outcome: Godfrey sees but doesn't take it — too risky
immediate_effects: Godfrey calculates odds, decides against theft
Diamond found with Franklin next morning
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Moderately plausible. Godfrey is calculating. But his desperation and the perfect opportunity make theft very tempting.

alternatives.outcome: Godfrey takes it but is seen by a servant
immediate_effects: Godfrey must bribe, threaten, or explain
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Godfrey is careful and the household is asleep. But servants do move at night.

alternatives.outcome: Godfrey tries to return it later when things get hot
immediate_effects: No one is exonerated or condemned
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Once pawned, the diamond is in the moneylender's hands. Godfrey can't easily retrieve it.

hinges.description: Rosanna commits suicide at the Shivering Sand
hinges.actual_outcome: Rosanna drowns herself, leaving letter and nightgown in the quicksand

alternatives.outcome: Rosanna runs away instead of killing herself
immediate_effects: She takes the nightgown with her
Franklin never learns the truth from her
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Moderately plausible. Flight is an alternative to death. But where would she go? Her criminal record limits options.

alternatives.outcome: Rosanna confesses everything to Franklin before dying
immediate_effects: Her feelings are revealed in person
Franklin might try to stop her
Evidence and motive are immediately clear
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Rosanna is too ashamed and shy. The letter is her way of speaking without facing him.

alternatives.outcome: Someone stops her at the Shivering Sand
immediate_effects: Her hiding of evidence comes out
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. The Shivering Sand is isolated. Her timing is deliberate.

alternatives.outcome: Rosanna survives the attempt
immediate_effects: Must face consequences of her concealment
Living testimony rather than posthumous letter
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility given the nature of the Shivering Sand. But quicksand deaths aren't always certain.

hinges.description: Dr. Candy falls ill with brain fever
hinges.actual_outcome: Candy's illness prevents him from remembering or revealing what he did

alternatives.outcome: Candy doesn't get ill — remembers everything
immediate_effects: Candy realizes what the laudanum caused
He could confess and exonerate Franklin
Mystery solved but Candy's career destroyed
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible as counterfactual. His illness is convenient but medically arbitrary. He could easily have stayed healthy.

alternatives.outcome: Candy dies from the fever
immediate_effects: Jennings has no puzzle to solve
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible. Brain fever was often fatal. His survival is fortunate.

alternatives.outcome: Candy confesses during the fever clearly enough to be understood
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Fever-ravings are fragmentary by nature. Clear confession would be unusual.

hinges.actual_outcome: Jennings meticulously documents the fragmentary confessions

alternatives.outcome: Jennings doesn't think to record the ravings
immediate_effects: No documentary evidence of the dosing
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Moderately plausible. Recording ravings is unusual medical practice. Jennings' curiosity is the key variable.

alternatives.outcome: Jennings records but keeps it private, never shares
immediate_effects: Evidence exists but is never used
Jennings' loyalty to Candy overrides justice
Franklin's fate depends on other evidence
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility given Jennings' character. He's dying and wants to do good. But doctor-patient loyalty is strong.

alternatives.outcome: Someone else attends Candy and hears the ravings
immediate_effects: Different person must piece it together
May or may not reach Franklin
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible. Jennings being the attendant is somewhat coincidental. Another doctor or nurse could have been present.

hinges.description: Jennings reconstructs the truth from fever-ravings
hinges.actual_outcome: Jennings pieces together that Candy dosed Franklin, proposes experiment

alternatives.outcome: Jennings fails to make sense of the fragments
immediate_effects: Franklin's name never cleared via this route
Rachel's secret knowledge becomes the only path
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible. The reconstruction requires brilliance and luck. Many would fail where Jennings succeeded.

alternatives.outcome: Jennings reconstructs it but dies before sharing
immediate_effects: His notes might be found posthumously
Someone else must interpret his work
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible. Jennings is terminally ill. Timing is everything.

alternatives.outcome: Jennings shares with the wrong person first
immediate_effects: Jennings' reputation (already damaged) undermines the claim
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Moderately plausible. Jennings is a social outcast. His word might not be trusted.

hinges.description: Godfrey observes Franklin with the diamond
hinges.actual_outcome: Godfrey happens to see Franklin wandering with diamond, follows him

alternatives.outcome: Godfrey is asleep and misses the whole thing
immediate_effects: Diamond ends up wherever sleepwalking Franklin leaves it
Found next morning, returned to Rachel
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Very plausible. Godfrey being awake and positioned to see Franklin is coincidental.

alternatives.outcome: Godfrey sees but interprets it as a dream/hallucination
immediate_effects: Doesn't act on what he saw
Later regrets not seizing the chance
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Godfrey is sharp and desperate. He'd recognize the opportunity.

alternatives.outcome: Godfrey wakes someone else to witness it
immediate_effects: Franklin's innocence might be more obvious
Godfrey can't steal without being suspected
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Very low plausibility. Why would Godfrey create witnesses to his opportunity? Against his interests.

hinges.description: Colonel Herncastle leaves diamond to Rachel in his will
hinges.actual_outcome: Herncastle's malicious bequest brings the cursed diamond into the Verinder household

alternatives.outcome: Herncastle destroys the diamond before death
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible. A guilty man might destroy the evidence of his crime. But Herncastle was proud of his conquest.

alternatives.outcome: Herncastle returns the diamond to India
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Low plausibility. Herncastle showed no remorse. Restitution would require character change.

alternatives.outcome: Herncastle leaves diamond to a museum
immediate_effects: Brahmins must target institution not family
No personal drama for the Verinders
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Plausible. Many collectors donated to museums. But Herncastle's bequest was malicious, targeting the family that rejected him.

alternatives.outcome: The family refuses the bequest
immediate_effects: Diamond goes elsewhere or to the state
Rachel never has her birthday disrupted
alternatives.plausibility_notes: Moderately plausible. The family knew the diamond was tainted. But refusing valuable inheritance is hard, and Rachel wanted it.
